results.abstract: Various black actors comment on difficulties they face getting roles; those commenting include Bill Duke, Dick Anthony Williams, Peter Andres and Glynn Turman; Sumi Haru, head of Screen Actors Guild ethnic minorities committee, says approximately 7.5% of membership is black, but they do not get nearly their share of jobs (M)

headline.main: Black Actors: 'Struggling for Crumbs'?; 'That's the Reality' More Immediate Concerns 'Keep a Low Profile'

results.snippet: LOS ANGELES "AN actor is powerless," says  Bill Duke. "But black actors are more than powerless. We're invisible. What that  does to you is insidious. It erodes your confidence about the very fact of your own existence."
results.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES "AN actor is powerless," says Bill Duke. "But black actors are more than powerless. We're invisible. What that does to you is insidious. It erodes your confidence about the very fact of your own existence."

results.abstract: USSR launches Soyuz 35 with cosmonauts Valery V Ryumin and Lt Col Leonid I Popov aboard; spacecraft to dock with orbiting Salyut 6 space station for mission of unreported duration (M)

headline.main: Manned Soviet Craft Lofted to Link With Space Lab; Goal of Soviet Program

results.snippet: MOSCOW April 9--Two Soviet astronauts, including one of the pair who spent a record 175 days orbiting the earth last year, were launched today on the Soyuz 35 craft toward the Salyut 6 space station for a mission of unreported duration.

byline.original: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY Special to The New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW April 9--Two Soviet astronauts, including one of the pair who spent a record 175 days orbiting the earth last year, were launched today on the Soyuz 35 craft toward the Salyut 6 space station for a mission of unreported duration.

results.abstract: Article on scene in Budapest, Hungary, focuses on use of anti-Soviet political jokes by city's residents; illustration (M)

headline.main: Hungary Wields One Weapon Against Moscow: Humor; The Talk of Budapest

results.snippet: BUDAPEST, April 22 Janos, a Hungarian poet with a mane of black hair that tumbled upon the shoulders of his cable-knit sweater, was nursing his seventh glass of Bull's Blood wine when a dozen Soviet soldiers walked by.

byline.original: By JOHN DARNTON Special to The New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: BUDAPEST, April 22 Janos, a Hungarian poet with a mane of black hair that tumbled upon the shoulders of his cable-knit sweater, was nursing his seventh glass of Bull's Blood wine when a dozen Soviet soldiers walked by.

results.abstract: Congressional reaction to Pres Carter's abortive mission ranges from bipartisan expressions of support to denunciations; Sen Henry M Jackson says abortive mission was disaster; Repr Henry S Reuss urges Carter to abandon his re-election campaign; Sens Frank Church and Jacob K Javits say Carter may nave violated War Powers Act; Carter briefs 24 Congressional leaders on mission; Senators Barry Goldwater, George McGovern, Alan Cranston and minority leader Howard H Baker Jr support Carter; sources say Sen majority leader Robert C Byrd was furious over not being informed of rescue attempt; illustrations of Senators Byrd, Birch Bayh and Theodore F Stevens on way to White House for briefing (M)

headline.main: Some in Congress Criticize Mission Because of a Lack of Consultation; Others Say President Couldn't Have Acted Differently and Urge Americans to Support the Military Move Carter Conducts Briefing

results.snippet: WASHINGTON, April 25 Congressional reaction to President Carter's abortive effort to free the American hostages in Iran ranged today from bipartisan expressions of support to denunciations by those who termed it "nothing short of a disaster" and...

byline.original: By MARTIN TOLCHIN Special to The New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 25 Congressional reaction to President Carter's abortive effort to free the American hostages in Iran ranged today from bipartisan expressions of support to denunciations by those who termed it "nothing short of a disaster" and urged Mr. Carter to abandon his re-election campaign.

results.abstract: Talese, Gay: Thy Neighbor's Wife reviewed by Anatole Broyard

headline.main: Books of The Times; Pontifications A Shared Responsibility

results.snippet: "THY NEIGHBOR'S WIFE" raises an interesting ques  tion: Do "liberated" Americans enjoy more sexual activity, or do they simply like to talk about it, read about and look at it in magazines and films?
results.lead_paragraph: "THY NEIGHBOR'S WIFE" raises an interesting ques tion: Do "liberated" Americans enjoy more sexual activity, or do they simply like to talk about it, read about and look at it in magazines and films?
